title: Deja-Vu: Seven Apple Features You May Recognise
text:
Sponsored By Deja-Vu: Seven Apple Features You May Recognise The tech giant is not averse to spotting good ideas elsewhere and adding them to its own range of products. 11:59, UK, Thursday 10 September 2015 Apple chief executive Tim Cook on stage at Wednesday's event Share by email Apple unveiled a raft of new features at its big event in San Francisco, but some of them left tech-watchers with a severe case of deja-vu. 
The iPad Pro - complete with stylus - is very similar to Microsoft's Surface 3 device, and both tablet computers are aimed at the business and creative world. 
Meanwhile, a selfie-optimised front-facing camera relies on the screen flashing white in low-light situations, but this feature appears already on apps including Snapchat. 
But it shouldn't come as much of a surprise. Apple is noted for looking at the best innovations of its rivals, then polishing them up and implementing them in Apple products. 
Fingerprint identification 
The iPhone 5s came with fingerprint recognition, allowing you to unlock a secured phone with the tap of a finger. iPhones and iPads can be unlocked using a fingerprint 
The HP iPaq PPC 5500 PC - released in 2003 - featured a reader strip which had to be swiped to unlock the computer. 
Voice-activated personal assistant Play video "New iPhone: Show And Tell" Video: New iPhone: Show And Tell 
Siri is now an important part of the Apple experience, featuring on both the iPhone and iPad, and soon to appear on Apple TV. 
But now defunct US company Wildfire Communications launched a telephone-based assistant in 1994. 
You could speak to it and ask it to help you place calls and listen to voicemails. 
Tablet computers 
Apple revolutionised the tablet industry when it launched the iPad in 2010. 
However, the concept of the tablet computer was first realistically floated in 1968, when computer scientist outlined his vision for a portable computer aimed at children. It was never built. 
Apple went on to release its first tablet - the Newton MessagePad 100 - in 1993. 
Low power mode 
In the new iOS 9 software, Apple offers users the option to enter 'low power mode' when battery is low. 
Apple trumpets the feature on its website, yet Android users have had the ability to save power in this way for four years. 1 / 10 Gallery: In Pictures: Apple's Big Launch The brand new range of Apple iPhones, featuring new '3D Touch' screen technology, were unveiled at Apple's big launch event in San Francisco 
Apple Music 
Apple's new music streaming service was launch in June with much fanfare. Users were offered a three-month free trial to get them on board. 
But Apple is playing catch up: Spotify has been around since 2008, offering full streaming for around Â£10 a month. But other partially on-demand services such as Pandora have been around since 2000. 
News 
Apple's new iOS 9 app is simply called News. 
It'll bring together the latest stories from publishers around the world, including Sky News. 
But despite the hype, it's very similar to news aggregators which have been around since the 90s. 
iOS Notes 
Notes in iOS 9 are finally fully featured, with check lists, integrated doodling, and image import options. 
But Google Keep and Evernote already offer these features, and again, Apple is playing catch up.
